messages.messageBody:
I've added the second page of the genealogy, and will add the rest as
time permits - otherwise, you can find more emperor genealogy on
the "Ogasawara Clan Genealogy site" -

http://hometown.aol.com/uchuujin/oga.html

The clan genealogy includes genealogy of some of the earliest
emperors of Japan.

CEWest

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Genealogy Books Available?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, Tony, Thanks for your prompt reply.  I am particularly interested in the lineages of the various mothers of the Emperors, from the time of TEMNU TENNO up
messages.messageBody:
Hi, Tony,

Thanks for your prompt reply. I am particularly
interested in the lineages of the various mothers of
the Emperors, from the time of TEMNU TENNO up to MEIJI
TENNO.

As you know, they usually have either a FUJIWARA or a
MINAMOTO family name.

Bob

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Genealogy Books Available?
messages.msgSnippet: ... Be warned that Papinot is rife with errors large and small, and is a product of its time. Unfortunately, there is nothing else in English that is both so
messages.messageBody:
brobpatus@... wrote:

> I am a retired history professor with a special interest in Medieval
> Japanese History.....I have a copy of Papinot, but I was wondering if
> there are other sources which give detailed genealogies of the
> various Daimyo and Samurai families as well as the Imperial Family?

Be warned that Papinot is rife with errors large and small, and is a
product of its time. Unfortunately, there is nothing else in English that
is both so concise and so detailed.

If you speak Japanese, there are many excellent sources I can point you to,
but if not, it's a bit more difficult. Any particular area or period you're
most interested in?

Tony

messages.subject: Re: Genealogy Books Available?
messages.msgSnippet: In the Japanese Language, there are plenty.  One series worth mentioning is the Rekishi Gunzo series, which is a series of Japanese history books. Each book
messages.messageBody:
In the Japanese Language, there are plenty. One series worth
mentioning is the "Rekishi Gunzo" series, which is a series of
Japanese history books. Each book covers a particular person, or
battle, with full color maps, pictures, and especially Genealogies.
I found a treasure trove of Mori genealogy in the 'Mori Motonari'
Rekishi Gunzo book - It had information on not only the Mori
genealogy but on the Amako and Ouchi as well. We actually have some
genealogies which we have translated on the Samurai Archives page:

http://samurai.bigsitecity.com/clanindex.html

Most of these only cover the 'sengoku' timeframe, and the "offline"
versions go farther back, and some are far more complete than others.
I have some in depth genealogy from (if I remember correctly) the
10th - 12th century on a few clans that a friend was able to get for
me, I believe they covered the Minamoto and Taira, but I don't have
them with me right now, (I'm at work). I'd have to scan them into my
computer to make them available.

CEWest

messages.subject: Genealogy Books Available?
messages.msgSnippet: I am a retired history professor with a special interest in Medieval Japanese History.....I have a copy of Papinot, but I was wondering if there are other
messages.messageBody:
I am a retired history professor with a special interest in Medieval
Japanese History.....I have a copy of Papinot, but I was wondering if
there are other sources which give detailed genealogies of the
various Daimyo and Samurai families as well as the Imperial Family?

Bob
